prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations aimed at detection of continuum and CO(2-1) line

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The primary aim of this science goal is the detection of continuum in 3 systems which were undetected in our pilot survey, so we maximise this possibility in 3 basebands by chosing a large bandwidth (1.875 Ghz) and low resolution (31.25 Mhz). In baseband 4, we aim for the detection of CO(2-1) which has a chance of being detected in these systems, but we keep a large baseband (1.875 GHz) and relativly low resolution (976.6 kHz) to optimise the remainder of these channels for further continuum observations. The continuum sensitivity of these observations implies an rms just above 3 mJy for CO(2-1) detection, which is exactly that required to detect the gas in these systems. We consider the spectral resolution for the CO sufficuient, as we are aiming for primarily for detection and therfore only require marginal resolution.

We aim to maximise the sensitivity for the detetion of continuum emission, and we therefore do not want to reolve our targets. We do however, require a beam size capable of resolving any wide binaries of separations greater than 0.7 arcseconds. Consequently, we request these observations be carried out in a compact configuration such as C36-3.

The main driver of this science goal is to detect the continuum emission of these disks in Band 6. Our pilot survey reached a rms of 0.16 mJy, and many systems were not detected at this level. The systems all display a near or mid-IR exces however, proving the existence of circumstellar dust. SED modelling of the available photometery reveals that a a peak flux of just under 0.12 mJy is expected in most systems, and an rms of 0.032mJy will therefore unambiguously detect the continuum emission. These detections will allow us to charaterse the individual disks as either debris disks or an earlier transitional phase. Based on the ALMA OT calculator, the requested continuum sensitivity translates to a total of 2.17 hours for this science case, including overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations aimed at detection of continuum in Band 3 only.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The only aim of this science goal is the detection of the continuum emission in band 3, and we therefore optimise all basebands for this goal, with the mazimum bandiwdth across all basebands (7.5 GHz), and the lowest spectral resolution (31.25 MHz).

We aim to maximise the sensitivity for the detetion of continuum emission, and we therefore do not want to reolve our targets. We do however, require a beam size capable of resolving any wide binaries of separations greater than 0.7 arcseconds. Consequently, we request these observations be carried out in a compact configuration such as C36-4.

The only driver of this science goal is to detect the continuum emission of these disks in Band 3. Our pilot survey reached a rms of 0.16 mJy, and many systems were not detected at this level. The 2 systems in this science goal have many photometery points in the near and mid-IR, and were also detected at 1.3 mm in our pilot survey. This allows us to perform SED modeling to predict a peak flux density of 0.13 mJy for the lowest mass system. There is some uncertaintly in this SED firring forcedure, and our rms was therefore set at 0.03 mJy to ensure these systems will be detected. These observations will allow us to contrain the grain size distrubution of the disks, and infer their stage of evolution. Based on the ALMA OT calculator, the requested continuum sensitivity translates to a total of 47.08 minutes for this science case, including overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations aimed at detection of continuum and CO(2-1) line

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The primary aim of this science goal is the detection of continuum in 3 systems which were undetected in our pilot survey, so we maximise this possibility in 3 basebands by chosing a large bandwidth (1.875 Ghz) and low resolution (31.25 Mhz). In baseband 4, we aim for the detection of CO(2-1) which has a high chance of being detected in these systems, but we keep a large baseband (1.875 GHz) and relativly low resolution (976.6 kHz) to optimise the remainder of these channels for further continuum observations. The continuum sensitivity of these observations implies an rms just above 3 mJy for CO(2-1) detection, which is exactly that required to detect the gas in these systems. We consider the spectral resolution for the CO sufficuient, as we are aiming for primarily for detection and therfore only require marginal resolution.

We aim to maximise the sensitivity for the detetion of continuum emission, and we therefore do not want to reolve our targets. We do however, require a beam size capable of resolving any wide binaries of separations greater than 0.7 arcseconds. Consequently, we request these observations be carried out in a compact configuration such as C36-3.

The main driver of this science goal is to detect the continuum emission of these disks in Band 6. Our pilot survey reached a rms of 0.16 mJy, and many systems were not detected at this level. The systems all display a near or mid-IR exces however, proving the existence of circumstellar dust. SED modelling of the available photometery reveals that a a peak flux of just under 0.12 mJy is expected in most systems, and an rms of 0.032mJy will therefore unambiguously detect the continuum emission. These detections will allow us to charaterse the individual disks as either debris disks or an earlier transitional phase. Based on the ALMA OT calculator, the requested continuum sensitivity translates to a total of 2.51 hours for this science case, including overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The evolution of circumstellar disks from their gas-rich protoplanetary to gas-poor debris stages is not well understood. Photoevaporation models are often invoked to explain this process but the mass-loss rates predicted by different models do not agree, resulting in uncertain time-scales for the final stages of disk clearing. The best candidates for studying this final stage are weak-line T-Tauri stars (WTTS) with an IR excess caused by circumstellar material. In a recent paper based on ALMA data, we studied a sample of these WTTS disks and find they are an inhomogeneous group, displaying very different properties. Many of the WTTS disks contain dust masses low enough to remain undetected in continuum, suggesting they may be debris disk analogues. A few rare disks were detected in continuum and may be photoevaporating disks, but their CO remains undetected, preventing a conclusive characterisation. We here propose to conclusively characterise a selection of these WTTS disks with observations in Bands 3 and 6 continuum, and 12CO(2-1). These results will have profound implications for disk evolution, giving new constraints to dissipation time-scales and disk evolution models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00350.S "Probing photoevaporation in protoplanetary disks: the primordial to debris disk transition" PI: Caceres 2011.0.00733.S "Towards a global understanding of circumstellar disk evolution" PI: M. Schreiber
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
